title: Simplifying a Fraction
solution_hints: Find the highest common factor (HCF) of 18 and 24.
Divide both numerator and denominator by the HCF.
common_pitfalls: Only dividing by 2 once and stopping at 9/12.
Thinking 18 and 24 have no larger common factor than 3.

title: Improper to Mixed Number
solution_hints: Divide 45 by 8 to find the whole-number part.
The remainder becomes the new numerator.
common_pitfalls: Using 8 5/8 by mistaking quotient and remainder.
Leaving the answer as an improper fraction.

title: Adding Unlike Denominators
problem_text: Find \(\dfrac{2}{3}+\dfrac{5}{12}\). Express your answer in its simplest form.
solution_hints: Rewrite both fractions with a common denominator.
Add the numerators, keep the denominator.
common_pitfalls: Adding denominators (3+12) instead of finding LCM.
Leaving the improper fraction 13/12 without converting.

title: Subtraction with Unlike Denominators
solution_hints: Use the lowest common denominator (LCD) of 8 and 12.
Subtract the numerators once rewritten.
common_pitfalls: Using 96 as denominator when 24 is smaller.
Subtracting smaller fraction first without aligning denominators.

title: Multiplying by a Whole Number
problem_text: Find \(\dfrac{3}{5}\times4\). Give your answer as a mixed number.
solution_hints: Change the whole number to a fraction with denominator 1.
Multiply the numerators and denominators.
Convert the improper fraction to mixed form.
common_pitfalls: Multiplying only numerator by 4 and keeping denominator 5 unchanged is correct—don’t also multiply denominator.
Forgetting to convert 12/5 to 2 2/5.

title: Dividing a Whole Number by a Fraction
solution_hints: Keep the first number, change ÷ to ×, flip the second fraction.
Simplify before multiplying if possible.
common_pitfalls: Multiplying instead of dividing (6×3/4).
Not inverting the divisor.

title: Fraction ÷ Fraction
solution_hints: Invert the second fraction and multiply.
Simplify the product if possible.
common_pitfalls: Multiplying the denominators instead of inverting and multiplying.
Not converting 15/4 to 3 3/4.

title: Re-packing Rice
problem_text: A bag contains \(\dfrac{3}{4}\) kg of rice. It is repacked equally into packets of \(\dfrac{1}{8}\) kg each. How many packets can be filled?
solution_hints: Express the situation as \(\dfrac{3}{4}÷\dfrac{1}{8}\).
Divide by inverting the divisor.
common_pitfalls: Multiplying 3/4 by 1/8.
Leaving the answer as \(\dfrac{6}{1}\) instead of 6 packets.

title: Spending Money in Parts
problem_text: John spent \(\dfrac{2}{5}\) of his money on books and \(\dfrac{1}{4}\) of the remainder on snacks. What fraction of his money did he spend in total?
solution_hints: Find the fraction of money remaining after buying books.
Take \(\dfrac{1}{4}\) of that remainder for snacks.
Add both spending fractions.
common_pitfalls: Taking 1/4 of the original amount instead of the remainder.
Adding unlike denominators without common denominator.

title: Sharing Pizza Equally
problem_text: Five friends share \(\dfrac{3}{2}\) of a pizza equally. What fraction of a whole pizza does each friend receive?
solution_hints: Divide the total pizza by 5.
Simplify the resulting fraction.
common_pitfalls: Multiplying instead of dividing.
Leaving answer as \(\dfrac{3}{2}÷5 = \dfrac{3}{10}\) without simplification (already simplest here).
verified_methodology: Step 2: Each friend gets 3/10 of a pizza.

title: Comparing Fractions
solution_hints: Cross-multiply to compare without converting to decimals.
Compare 7×8 with 5×12.
common_pitfalls: Comparing denominators only (thinking smaller denominator means larger value without checking numerators).
Cross-multiplying inaccurately.

title: Adding Mixed Numbers
solution_hints: Convert 3 2/7 to an equivalent fraction with denominator 14.
Add whole numbers and fractional parts separately.
Simplify if necessary.
common_pitfalls: Adding only fractional parts and forgetting whole numbers.
Not converting to common denominators.

title: Water Tank Usage
problem_text: A water tank was \(\dfrac{3}{4}\) full. After some water was used, \(\dfrac{2}{9}\) of the tank’s capacity was gone. What fraction of the tank remains filled?
solution_hints: Express both amounts with a common denominator.
Subtract the used fraction from the original fraction.
common_pitfalls: Subtracting 2/9 from 1 instead of from 3/4.
Using 1 as a common denominator.
verified_methodology: Step 3: 19/36 of the tank remains filled.

title: Scaling a Recipe
problem_text: A recipe needs \(\dfrac{2}{3}\) cup of sugar per batch. How many cups of sugar are required for 3 \(\dfrac{1}{2}\) batches?
solution_hints: Convert the mixed number to an improper fraction.
Multiply the fractions and simplify.
common_pitfalls: Adding instead of multiplying.
Leaving answer as improper fraction 7/3.
